thread.title: SEE IT: All passengers survive burning South Sudan pane
thread.title_full: SEE IT: All passengers survive burning South Sudan pane

author: JASON SILVERSTEIN
title: SEE IT: All passengers survive burning South Sudan pane
text:
The burning plane at Wau Airport. (HAND OUT/AFP/Getty Images) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Tuesday, March 21, 2017, 8:14 AM 
All 49 people on a passenger plane in South Sudan survived on Monday after it crash-landed and burst into flames, officials said. 
The South Supreme Airlines carrier was traveling from Juba to Wau in cloudy skies when it crashed during its landing, Wau's Acting Airport Manager Stephen Youngule said. 
“The plane touched down and then jumped up again. The pilot couldn't control it,” Youngule told The Associated Press. 
“I saw it until the very last moment before the fire engulfed the aircraft.” 
Videos from the scene captured the burning plane on the runway. 
When it crashed, the plane's doors busted open, allowing all 44 passengers and five crew members to escape, officials said. An unknown number were hospitalized for injuries. All 49 passengers and crew survive as plane crash-lands and bursts into flames at airport in South Sudan. https://t.co/gT8SOKr0lP pic.twitter.com/KAwY2PKvw3 — ABC News (@ABC) March 21, 2017 
A spokesperon for President Salva Kiir Mayardit called the result of the crash “miracoulous.” 
“It is miraculous, completely. There are only minor injuries. There was no single death,” Ateny Wek Ateny said. 
Most passengers were South Sudanese, except for one traveler from China and another from Eritrea, officials said. 
Ateny said the pilot overshot the runway and landed on unpaved ground. 
With News Wire Services
